system — Generic system simulation¶

This module provides basic utilities to build system simulations based on ordinary differential equations (ODE).

Available types and functions¶

class system.System[source]¶

Bases: builtins.object

Objects of this class represent abstract dynamical systems (in physics, electronics, hydraulics etc.) governed by an ordinary differential equation (ODE):

\[\begin{split}\begin{array}{rcl} \frac{\mathbf{d}s}{\mathbf{d}t} & = & F(t,s) \end{array}\end{split}\]

where \(s\) is the state and \(t\) is time. The ODE numerical solver used is taken from module scipy.integrate which assumes the state is a numpy.array. For display purposes, each state is associated with two pieces of information:

  • a “live” display information which the object must be capable of interpreting to actually display the state, and
  • a “shadow” display information which the object buffers during a simulation and must be capable of interpreting to render a shadow of the last states.

Attributes defined in subclasses (or preferably at instance level for efficiency):

main¶

The function \(F\) defining the ODE.

jacobian¶

The derivative of function \(F\) defining the ODE as \(J_{uv}(t,s)=\frac{\partial F_u}{\partial s_v}\), or None if the Jacobian is too costly to compute (it is only used as an optimisation by the ODE solver). If the state space is of dimension \(d\), then the Jacobian must be of dimension \(d\times d\).

fordisplay¶

A function which, given a state, returns the pair of the live and shadow display information associated with that state.

Methods:

display(ax, disp, animate=None, tailn=None, srate=None, **ka)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • ax (matplotlib.Axes instance) – matplotlib axes on which to display
  • disp – a display function (see below)
  • simul – argument dictionary for the simulation (passed to method runstep())
  • animate – animation function
  • tailn – length of the shadow
  • ini – initial state of the system
  • srate – sampling rate in 1/s

Runs a simulation of the system and displays it in ax as an animation.

This method is meant to be overridden in subclasses to perform some initialisations on ax and provide appropriate values for parameter disp, which must be a function with two arguments: live (live display information) and tail (array of the last tailn shadow display information), and which actually performs the display.

launch(fig={'figsize': (9, 9)}, animate={}, **ka)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • animate – animation optional parameters (as a dictionary)
  • fig – figure optional parameters (as a dictionary)
  • ka – passed to display()

Creates matplotlib axes, then runs a simulation of the system and displays it as an animation on those axes, using the matplotlib.animation animation functionality.

runstep(ini, srate, maxtime=inf)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • ini – initial state of the system
  • srate – sampling rate in 1/s
  • maxtime – simulation time in s (default to infinity)

Runs a simulation of the system from the initial state ini (time 0) until maxtime, sampled at rate srate. The elements are returned by an iterator.
